nodes.bodyText:
can be assigned to a yaml alias for reuse in job build_maven
similarly the docker params below.
For eg
references:
  maven_docker: &maven_docker
      docker:
        - image: adoptopenjdk:11-jdk-hotspot
        - image: postgres:9.6-alpine
          environment:
            POSTGRES_DB: mirror_node_test
            POSTGRES_PASSWORD: mirror_node_pass
            POSTGRES_USER: mirror_node

and then here
-*maven_docker
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -116,6 +122,27 @@ jobs:
             tar -czf ${WORKSPACE}/artifacts/${NAME}.tgz -C ${WORKSPACE} ${NAME}
       - *persist_artifacts
 
+  perf_maven:
+    environment:
+      MAVEN_CLI_OPTS: --batch-mode --no-transfer-progress --show-version -Dorg.slf4j.simpleLogger.log.org.apache.maven.cli.transfer.Slf4jMavenTransferListener=warn

nodes.bodyText: do we want to keep this general (and add balance tests here in future) or keep it just for record and isolate balance test in other class?
It should be record specific. Recommend adding Record to name
I envisioned multiple classes, so the later.
we can make filter string a param and move rest of the code here to parse(..) too

imo, running it for every commit might be overkill right now since it doesn't need to be run for grpc, rest, and most general commits. That said, perf regressions can creep in unexpectedly. So maybe later on, we should setup to run perf test in nightly/periodic manner.
up to you, just suggestion.

               ignore: /.*/
             tags:
               only: /^.*/
+      - perf_maven:

nodes.bodyText: I think the goal was to have it run every time to not miss something

nodes.bodyText: Agreed though a nightly run instead with maybe larger datasets would be a good idea also

nodes.bodyText:
imo, just this one  is enough.
Others will have too less of runtime and data (data point for single file) to be of much significance.
Just this test is perfect, one run of this will be good enough data point to be significant since it's ingesting multiple files(so in a way, it's aggregate of multiple data points), and running for extended time.
Up to you, just a suggestion.
Agreed

I thought the 5000 and 10000 case might offer smaller units that you can use to estimate performance when you're not able to run tests or need to do a quick estimate e.g. we've seen 5k use of a record file produced at 1k tps take x, so in y scenario it might take z.
Granted this assumes linear relationship which may not hold with the the table indexes

We don't need to worry about non-automated use cases like quick estimates. Goal here is to push multiple files through to validate performance doesn't regress  and run those tests on every commit or nightly if tests take too long to run.
Reduced it to the single one
It's more important to run cleanup before than after, but can just add both
Will add
Recommend just using @Timeout on each test method and removing this parse method. Logging not necessary
Good idea
There should be some sort of warmup in a @BeforeAll or @BeforeEach to get accurate performance numbers
Done
These files should be in a different folder than the normal v1 and v2 tests. Suggestion: src/test/resources/data/recordstreams/performance/. It doesn't need the name of the node account id.
Done

I would like to see JUnit tags used to find performance tests instead of properties. That is, go ahead and run both unit and integration tests and configure excludedGroups to be !performance. We could potentially have unit tests that micro benchmark classes that we want to run as part of this profile too.

nodes.bodyText: @Tag("performance"). Also, since most of our tests can be considered integration tests (they all extend IntegrationTest and start a DB), can we rename this to end in test? I think if you use groups and tags to include/exclude maven failsafe it should pick that suffix up.
Same comment as above. Had tried with a @tag("benchmark") with no luck but might have been blocked by other issues. Will revisit to get it working.
These can be removed now, I believe
